abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>BRCA1 and BRCA2 play a central role in DNA repair and their germline pathogenic variants (g<jats:italic>BRCA</jats:italic>) confer a high risk for developing breast and ovarian cancer. Standard chemotherapy regimens for these cancers include DNA-damaging agents. We hypothesized that <jats:italic>gBRCA</jats:italic> carriers might be at higher risk of developing chemotherapy-related hematologic toxicity and therapy-related myeloid neoplasms (t-MN). We conducted a retrospective study of women newly diagnosed with invasive breast or ovarian cancer who were screened for <jats:italic>gBRCA1/gBRCA2</jats:italic> at Geneva University Hospitals. All patients were treated with (neo-)adjuvant chemotherapy. We evaluated acute hematologic toxicities by analyzing the occurrence of febrile neutropenia and severe neutropenia (grade 4) at day 7–14 of the first cycle of chemotherapy and G-CSF use during the entire chemotherapy regimen. Characteristics of t-MN were collected. We reviewed medical records from 447 patients: 58 g<jats:italic>BRCA1</jats:italic> and 40 gBRCA2 carriers and 349 non-carriers. <jats:italic>gBRCA1</jats:italic> carriers were at higher risk of developing severe neutropenia (32% vs. 14.5%, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.007; OR = 3.3, 95% CI [1.6-7], <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.001) and of requiring G-CSF for secondary prophylaxis (58.3% vs. 38.2%, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.011; OR = 2.5, 95% CI [1.4–4.8], <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.004). <jats:italic>gBRCA2</jats:italic> carriers did not show increased acute hematologic toxicities. t-MN were observed in 2 patients (1 <jats:italic>gBRCA1</jats:italic> and one non-carrier). Our results suggested an increased acute hematologic toxicity upon exposure to chemotherapy for breast and ovarian cancer among <jats:italic>gBRCA1</jats:italic> but not <jats:italic>gBRCA2</jats:italic> carriers. A deeper characterization of t-MN is warranted with the recent development of PARP inhibitors in frontline therapy in <jats:italic>gBRCA</jats:italic> breast and ovarian cancer.</jats:p>
publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC

title: Hematologic toxicities of chemotherapy in breast and ovarian cancer patients carrying BRCA1/BRCA2 germline pathogenic variants. A single center experience and review of the literature
